head.title: Photonic excess noise and wave localization

article.h1: Photonic excess noise and wave localization

span.span: C. W. J. Beenakker and M. Patra
Instituut-Lorentz, Universiteit Leiden, P.O. Box 9506, 2300 RA Leiden, The Netherlands
Laboratory of Atomic and Solid State Physics, Cornell University, Ithaca NY 14853, USA

div.p: This is a theory for the effect of localization on the super-Poissonian noise of radiation propagating through an absorbing disordered waveguide. Localization suppresses both the mean photon current IÂ¯Â¯ğ¼OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-I ARG:end\bar{I} and the noise power Pğ‘ƒitalic-PP, but the Fano factor P/IÂ¯ğ‘ƒÂ¯ğ¼italic-P MULOP:divide OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-I ARG:endP/\bar{I} is found to remain unaffected. For strong absorption the Fano factor has the universal value 1+32â¢f132ğ‘“NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:3 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end italic-f1+\frac{3}{2}f (with fğ‘“italic-ff the Bose-Einstein function), regardless of whether the waveguide is long or short compared to the localization length.

The coherent radiation from a laser has Poisson statistics [1, 2]. Its noise power PPoissonsubscriptğ‘ƒPoissonitalic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start Poisson POSTSUBSCRIPT:endP_{\rm Poisson} equals the mean current IÂ¯Â¯ğ¼OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-I ARG:end\bar{I} (in units of photons per second). Elastic scattering has no effect on the noise, because the radiation remains in a coherent state. The coherent state is degraded by absorption, resulting in an excess noise P-PPoisson>0ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘ƒPoisson0italic-P ADDOP:minus italic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start Poisson POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:0P-P_{\rm Poisson}>0 [3]. The Fano factor P/PPoissonğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘ƒPoissonitalic-P MULOP:divide italic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start Poisson POSTSUBSCRIPT:endP/P_{\rm Poisson} deviates from unity by an amount proportional to the Bose-Einstein function fğ‘“italic-ff. It is a small effect (fâˆ¼10-2similar-toğ‘“superscript102italic-f RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endf\sim 10^{-2} at room temperature for infrared frequencies), but of interest because of its fundamental origin: The excess noise is required to preserve the canonical commutation relations of the electromagnetic field in an absorbing dielectric [4, 5, 6].

The interference of multiply scattered waves may lead to localization [7]. Localization suppresses both the mean current and the fluctuations â€” on top of the suppression due to absorption. Localization is readily observed in a waveguide geometry [8], where it sets in once the length Lğ¿italic-LL of the waveguide becomes longer than the localization length Î¾â‰ƒNâ¢lsimilar-to-or-equalsğœ‰ğ‘ğ‘™italic-xi RELOP:similar-to-or-equals italic-N italic-l\xi\simeq Nl (with lğ‘™italic-ll the mean free path and Nğ‘italic-NN the number of propagating modes). Typically, Î¾ğœ‰italic-xi\xi is much larger than the absorption length Î¾asubscriptğœ‰aitalic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start a POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\xi_{\rm a}, so that localization and absorption coexist. The interplay of absorption and localization has been studied previously for the mean current [9, 10, 11, 12]. Here we go beyond these studies to include the current fluctuations.

It is instructive to contrast the super-Poissonian photonic noise with the sub-Poissonian electronic analogue. In the case of electrical conduction through a disordered wire, the (zero-temperature) noise power is smaller than the Poisson value as a result of Fermi-Dirac statistics. The reduction is a factor 1/313NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:31/3 in the absence of localization [13, 14]. The effect of localization is to restore Poisson statistics, so that the Fano factor increases from 1/313NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:31/3 to 1 when Lğ¿italic-LL becomes larger than Î¾ğœ‰italic-xi\xi. What we will show in this paper is that the photonic excess noise responds entirely differently to localization: Although localization suppresses Pğ‘ƒitalic-PP and IÂ¯Â¯ğ¼OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-I ARG:end\bar{I}, the Fano factor remains unaffected, equal to the value 1+32â¢f132ğ‘“NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:3 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end italic-f1+\frac{3}{2}f obtained in the absence of localization [15, 16].

In conclusion, we have demonstrated that localization of radiation in an absorbing disordered waveguide has no effect on the ratio of the excess noise and the mean current. In the limit of a large number of propagating modes, this ratio is self-averaging and takes on the universal value of 3/232NUMBER:3 MULOP:divide NUMBER:23/2 times the Bose-Einstein function. Observation of this photonic analogue of the universal 1/313NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:31/3 reduction of electronic shot noise presents an experimental challenge.
